title-group.article-title: Log-linear Causal Analysis of Cross-classified Categorical Data

author-notes.corresp: Kazuo Yamaguchi, University of Chicago, Department of Sociology, 1126 E. 59th Street, NORC 349, Chicago, IL 60637, USA Email: kyamagu@uchicago.edu

abstract.p: Although log-linear and log-multiplicative analysis of association between variables is useful, its major limitation has been a lack of association with causal analysis. The objective of this article is to introduce a causal analysis on the basis of an adjusted cross-classified frequency table having such counterfactual odds ratios between a treatment variable X and its dependent variable Y that would be realized if the effects of confounding covariates on the association between X and Y were eliminated. The author first clarifies that the attainment of statistical independence between X and the covariates is not sufficient, because the issue of collapsibility remains even under completely randomized treatment allocation, and then proposes a specific standardization method for covariate states to solve this issue. By assuming semiparametric regression models, the author then introduces a new method of retaining the causal effects of X on Y, and the possible dependence of those effects on the third variable, in adjusted two-way or three-way contingency tables. As a result, the author also introduces a method for applying semiparametric logit and multinomial logit regression models that do not specify the effects of the confounding covariates V on Y. The estimation of standard errors for applying log-linear and log-multiplicative association models for the data of adjusted contingency tables is also described.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: This article has been organized around two related goals. First, I aim to obtain two-way and three-way tables of adjusted cross-classified frequency data that reflect the effects of categorical variable X on categorical variable Y that would be realized after eliminating selection bias in the effects of X on Y generated by confounding covariates V. Second, I aim to introduce a method for applying semiparametric logit and multinomial logit regression models that do not specify the effects of the confounding covariates V on Y.

The log-linear and log-multiplicative analysis of association among variables as a contingency table analysis has significant merits not only in characterizing association in quantity but also in revealing the pattern of association. For this reason, there were many applications of the method in a few areas of sociological research, including social mobility and assortative mating, and some applications in several other areas in the 1970s and 1980s. However, sociological researchers’ interest in the use of log-linear and log-multiplicative analyses of contingency tables seems to have been largely lost in the past two decades, mainly because of the limitations of the analyses for handling many control variables. Although log-linear models that are in the regression form, such as logit, multinomial logit, and ordered logit models, continue to be used frequently, the effectiveness of a multivariate regression form in controlling confounding variables for causal analysis has gradually been called into question, starting with the pioneering work of Rosenbaum and Rubin (1983, 1984) on the use of propensity score adjustments.

This article is a response to these trends, introducing a new log-linear causal analysis of a categorical dependent variable. Contingency table analysis of association among categorical variables has not been linked to causal analysis, except for the use of log-linear latent-trait models (Duncan 1985a, 1985b; Yamaguchi 1994) that are variants of person-specific fixed-effects models. But because those models require panel data and make some strong assumptions, they have not often been applied.

Semiparametric methods based on the use of the propensity score, including propensity score matching methods, especially the kernel-matching method (Heckman et al. 1998) and inverse probability weighting (IPW) on the basis of the propensity score (Rubin 1985), have been used widely. However, the use of these methods for models with logit or multinomial logit link functions has serious limitations. The propensity score tries to attain independence between the treatment variable X and the confounding covariates V in the pseudopopulation by conditioning semiparametrically on the propensity score. However, even under statistical independence between X and V, one cannot omit V from the regression equation for the logit and multinomial logit models to obtain unbiased estimates of X on Y (Gail, Weiand, and Piantadosi 1984).1 This is known as the lack of collapsibility for regressions with a logit link function. Because the primary aim of log-linear causal analysis for contingency table data is to generate an adjusted two-way contingency table of X by Y frequencies that retain the causal effects of X on Y when summed across the categories of V, the lack of collapsibility is a major problem. Because this issue is not widely recognized, in this article, I explain the problem formally and with illustrative examples.

The collapsibility problem described above can be solved if we try to eliminate selection bias in the effect of X on Y due to confounding variables V by eliminating the effects of V on Y instead of attaining independence between X and V. In particular, standardization methods for the odds, such as Xie’s (1989) “CD-purging” method, which eliminates the effects of V on Y, should work if

The main aim of this article is thus to develop a new standardization method to solve the collapsibility problem and the problem of zero estimates for conditional probabilities

From those adjusted conditional probabilities, we can generate two-way or three-way contingency tables of adjusted frequencies whose odds ratios reflect the causal effects of X on Y and the possible dependence of those effects on a covariate. I also describe how to estimate the standard errors of parameter estimates in the analysis of association and conditional association on the basis of the use of those adjusted frequency data. Finally, I present an application of the method using pooled data from the General Social Surveys.

sec.title: 2. Propensity Score Methods and the Collapsibility Problem for the Logit Model
sec.p:
Propensity score matching, originally introduced by Rosenbaum and Rubin (1983) and elaborated by Heckman et al. (1998), and IPW, based on propensity score estimates introduced by Rubin (1985) and extended for marginal structural models by Robins, Hernán, and Brumback (2000), have been used extensively as major tools for eliminating selection bias in the treatment variable. Their causal analysis based on counterfactuals makes a distinction between the treatment assignment characterized by observed variable X and the treatment that yields that outcome, and it can be counterfactual. When we have a dichotomous distinction of the treatment group for whom X = 1 and the control group for whom X = 0, we assume a pair of potential outcome variables, Y1 and Y0, for each subject for an outcome under the treatment and an outcome under no treatment, respectively (Morgan and Winship 2007). The one of those two that is counterfactual is considered missing because we observe only Y1 for the treatment group and only Y0 for the control group. The observed outcome variable is defined as
Y

To obtain a consistent estimate of the average treatment effect, Rosenbaum and Rubin (1983) assumed that the strongly ignorable treatment assignment (SITA) condition holds. The SITA assumption posits that both Y1 and Y0 are conditionally independent of the treatment assignment when conditioned by a set of covariates V—that is,

A problem of causal reasoning for logit and multinomial logit regression models here is that the average treatment effect based on regression equation 4 differs from the marginal treatment effect defined by equation 3. This can be readily inferred from the fact that, given equation 4, the marginal treatment effect is given as

Prior to a more formal analysis of this collapsibility problem and its solution, I first illustrate the problem by presenting simple examples with a dichotomous dependent variable Y, a dichotomous treatment variable X, and a single dichotomous covariate V.

The three data sets in Table 1 present distinct hypothetical 2 × 2 × 2 cross-classified frequencies where X is made independent of V for each data set. They respectively represent situations in which the interaction effect of X and V on Y is absent for the linear probability model (data set 1), the log-linear probability model (data set 2), and the logit model (data set 3), for the following specifications of the three models:

The issue of collapsibility is concerned with whether, given the statistical independence between X and V, we can retain the average treatment effect if we omit the effect of V from the regression models—or equivalently, if we analyze data summed across the states of V—by applying the following models with the same link function:

Table 2 shows the estimates of regression coefficients β1 and β2 obtained by applying regression models 5a, 5b, and 5c to each of the three data sets, and those of regression coefficient b obtained similarly by applying regression models 6a, 6b, and 6c. The “average β” in Table 2 is a weighted average of the treatment effects

caption.p: Analysis of Data Sets in Table 1

sec.p: The results of Table 2 show that

list-item.p: the linear probability model preserves the average treatment effect regardless of the presence of interaction effects of X and V on Y, and
the log-linear probability model preserves the average treatment effect only if there exist no interaction effects of X and V on Y, and
the logit model does not preserve the average treatment effect regardless of the presence of interaction effects of X and V on Y.

sec.p: In the next section, I formally prove that characteristics 1, 2, and 3 given above generally hold for any data. Finding characteristic 3 implies the lack of collapsibility for the logit model and indicates that the IPW method, which aims to attain independence between X and covariates V in weighted data, does not preserve the average treatment effect for the logit model when weighted data are aggregated across the covariates’ states.

sec.title: 3. On Standardization and the Lack of Collapsibility of the Logit Model
sec.p: This section formally demonstrates the problem described in the previous section and also shows the characteristics of standardization methods that provide guidance for solving the issue.

The standardization methods assume an outcome variable Y, a group variable X, and a categorical covariate C, and they are concerned with obtaining adjusted statistics for Y for each group—such as its means and proportions—under a counterfactual situation where covariate C is distributed independently of X.

sec.p: A proof of this theorem is given in Appendix A. I will describe here what this theorem means for the case in which the link function is a multinomial logit function, because we are concerned with the log-linear analysis of frequencies. According to part 1 of the theorem, that if the standardization function is either a multinomial logit function, such as

sec.title: 4.2. Method for Obtaining Adjusted Two-way Frequency Data for the Analysis of Association between X and Y
sec.p:
Let us assume below that all covariates V are categorical, or categorized, variables, and let us denote by C a categorical variable whose categories are combined states of covariates V, by excluding states of C with no sample observations. We indicate by

Hence, researchers should make sure that the proportion of such noninformative sample to be small for a given set of covariates, so as not to lose efficiency greatly.

sec.title: 4.3. Method for Obtaining an Adjusted Three-way Frequency Table for the Analysis of Conditional Association
sec.p:
Now we consider cases in which we can expect significant interaction effects of X and a particular covariate Z on Y. We consider this as an extension of the semiparametric model, for which we do not impose any constraints on the covariate effects, including Z, on Y. We can easily extend the method below for cases with two or more interacting covariates by treating the combined states of those covariates as Z. Let us denote by C the set of combined categories of covariates other than Z. For the reason explained in section 5, we assume that

where the beta parameters take a value of zero for the first category of each variable. We will call this model a conditionally additive effect model of the treatment variable and covariates because the effects of X on Y and the effects of C on Y are additive for each given state of Z.

The ML estimates of equation 15 can be obtained, without applying the regression model, by using the iterative proportional adjustment procedure described in Appendix B. As the appendix shows, the estimates for

On the other hand, the conditional log odds ratios between Z and Y at each level of X in the adjusted conditional probabilities become

sec.title: 5. The Estimation of Standard Errors in the Analysis of Association with Adjusted Contingency Table Data
sec.p: It is well known that the use of weighted data with which we obtain consistent estimates for the parameters of interest to us still generates bias in the estimates of the standard errors of the parameter estimates, because standard errors depend on unweighted sample counts. Clogg and Eliason (1987) introduced a method that attempted to solve this problem in log-linear analysis by fitting unweighted frequencies by the model while characterizing weighted frequencies by the model’s parameters. Skinner and Vallet (2010), however, have recently shown that the standard errors estimated by the Clogg-Eliason method have systematic downward bias and are inconsistent unless weights do not vary within each cell of the contingency table data. Because sampling weights vary with sample individuals within each cell, the Skinner-Vallet study invalidated the Clogg-Eliason method for contingency table data weighted by sampling weights.

However, we can use the Clogg-Eliason method for the present analysis. We wish to estimate parameters that characterize the adjusted frequencies in which causal relationship among variables is embedded, while fitting unadjusted sample counts for estimating standard errors. Unlike standard applications of log-linear models to contingency-table data, we do not need to take into account sampling weights, because if the semiparametric model we assume for the population is correct, the causal relationship between X and Y and its dependence on Z do not depend on the sampling variability. Hence, we only need to apply the adjustment weights for standardization, but unlike the sampling weights, the adjustment weights are cell specific and do not vary with sample individuals. Hence, as shown by Skinner and Vallet (2010), the Clogg-Eliason method becomes valid in this case. We denote below by
f
jk
XY
and
f
jkm
XYZ
the cross-classified unweighted observed frequencies, by
g
jk
XY
and
g
jkm
XYZ
the cross-classified adjusted frequencies on the basis of the application of the semiparametric models to unweighted data and the standardization method described in the preceding sections. For the two-way table analysis of adjusted cross-classified frequencies
g
jk
XY
, let us set “cell weight” to be
w

The estimates of those association parameters and their standard errors can be obtained via ML estimation, as in the standard application of log-linear and log-multiplicative association models with given cell weights.

sec.title: 6. Notes on Log-Linear “Purging” Methods
sec.p: This section is written for readers interested in the historical development of ideas on standardization of rates and conditional probabilities in log-linear analysis and can be skipped otherwise. From the late 1970s to 1980s, Clogg and his associates (Clogg 1978; Clogg and Eliason 1988; Clogg, Shockey, and Eliason 1990) and Xie (1989) developed various “purging” methods for the standardization of rates and conditional probabilities.

Those purging methods were concerned with an expression of rates, with variable D as the dichotomous dependent variable that distinguishes between the occurrence and the nonoccurrence of the event, as a function of the group variable G after eliminating the confounding effects of the composition variable C. The rate here implies the conditional probability
p ( d
|
c , g )
. Different from the present analysis, however, the group variable G is an exogenous variable, not the treatment variable, and the method was concerned with the retention of the unique or direct effects of G on D in the adjusted rates. Despite the difference in aim, the standardization generated by those purging methods are both special cases of the standardization method for the logit link function described in this article, except for the handling of the interaction effects of C and G on D, described below.

Let us express the saturated model for the CGD three-way frequencies as

If we apply the partial-CG purging method and the CD purging method for adjusted data after the elimination of the three-factor interactions by the ML method, they respectively become a special case of the standardization method of equations 9 and 10 with the logit link function. It can be proved that Xie’s (1989) CD purging method is equivalent of applying the standardization equation 9 with a uniform distribution,

w ( c )
at zero for categories of C involving zero estimates for C-state-specific conditional probabilities.

Finally, it is also noteworthy that if C is but a mediating variable that is affected by G, not an exogenous variable, and we are interested in estimating the direct effects of G by eliminating indirect effects through C, an implicit assumption that the elimination of indirect effects does not change direct effects must hold for those standardization methods to be valid, though such an assumption may not hold for the results of a social intervention (Yamaguchi 2011).

sec.title: 7.1. Data and Statistical Software
sec.p: We use the multiyear data of the General Social Surveys (1972–2008) with the population of people aged 20 to 79 years at the time of the survey. A particular trichotomous variable, happiness (“not happy,”“pretty happy,” and “very happy”) is used as the dependent variable, with 41,200 samples. As the treatment variable, marital status with five categories (married, widowed, divorced, separated, and never married) is used. Seven categorical covariates are used: (1) age (11 categories: 20–24, 25–29, 30–34, 35–39, 40–44, 45–49, 50–54, 55–59, 60–64, 65–69, 70–74, and 75–79 years), (2) education (5 categories: <12, 12, 13–15, 16, and >16 years), (3) gender, (4) race (2 categories: African American and other), (5) family intactness at age 16 (2 categories: intact and nonintact), (6) region of residence at age 16 (3 categories: foreign, Pacific, and other), (7) period (4 categories: 1972–1979, 1980–1989, 1990–1999, and 2000–2008).3 Despite a fairly large number of possible combined states of those seven covariates (5,280), covariate states that are observed just with one category of marital status and therefore not informative for the estimation of the effects of marital status on the dependent variable are only 4.3% of the sample.

Those seven covariates are significantly associated with both marital status and the dependent variable. Although the results are not presented because they are not central subjects of the present article, the multinomial logit model that assumes the additive effects of seven covariates indicates the following. All seven covariates showed strong effects, but marital status, especially “married” versus other marital statuses, is the strongest predictor of being “very happy” rather than “not happy.” Education and race also have impacts greater than the other four predictors, with lower education and being African American leading to lower odds of being “very happy” rather than “not happy.”
The program LEM (Vermunt 1997a, 1997b) is used for the application of the log-multiplicative association models.

sec.title: 7.2. Analysis
sec.p: We used three-way table analysis because significant interaction of the treatment variable (marital status) and a covariate (race) are found in the preliminary analysis. Hence, we employ race as the conditioning variable in models described in section 4.3. Table 3 presents (1) adjusted frequencies and (2) unweighted sample counts for the three-way table.

caption.p: Unweighted and Adjusted Frequencies of Happiness

sec.p: Table 4 presents the results from four multinomial logit models: (1) the multinomial logit model with marital status, race, and their interaction effects as the only predictors; (2) the multinomial logit model with additional additive effects of the six other covariates; (3) a third model that adds the interaction effects of age and race to the second model; and (4) the semiparametric multinomial logit model of equation 15. Table 4 omits the presentation of the main effects of race from all models, as well as the effects of the six covariates for models 2 and 3, because we are interested only in the effects of marital status and their dependence on race.

tr.th: The Effects of Marital Status (vs. Never Married)

tr.td: 1. Multinomial logit with marital status as the single predictor
2. Multinomial logit with marital status and seven other predictors
3. Model 2 plus the interaction effects of race and age

sec.p: The most conspicuous finding in Table 4 is the great difference in results between models 2 and 3. Although the effects of marital status on happiness change only a little among other races when the interaction effects of race and age are added, the results change greatly among African Americans. Because marital status and age are strongly associated, the interaction effects of race and age, if they are present, strongly affect the interaction effects of marital status and race, and a failure to include the former effects greatly distorts the latter effects.

Note that by including the interaction effects of age and race, the results of model 3 become closer, though not uniformly, to the results from the semiparametric multinomial logit model (model 4) than the results of model 2 are to those of model 4. Those findings indicate that the results from multinomial logit models that characterize the effects of covariates parametrically may depend heavily on a particular specification of the model regarding the covariates’ effects. On the other hand, the semiparametric model does not suffer from that problem.

Table 5 presents the results from applying conditional association models to the adjusted three-way frequency data of Table 3 using cell weights described in equation 22. A description of parameterizations for various conditional association models is given in the footnotes to Table 5, and their LEM specifications are described in Appendix C. These results show that all log-linear and log-multiplicative association models fail to fit the data by the likelihood ratio test. However, because the sample size is quite large, we may adopt an alternative criterion, the Bayesian information criterion (BIC), considered to be more robust than the likelihood ratio test in identifying the best-fitting model for a large sample. The negative values of BIC for all log-linear and log-multiplicative association models indicate that they are more parsimonious than the saturated model of the three-way table whose BIC value is 0. The parameter estimates of the saturated model for the association of happiness with marital status and its dependence on race are the same as those of the multinomial logit model 4 in Table 4, because model 4 is the semiparametric model of equation 15, with which the adjusted three-way frequencies were derived by standardization.

sec.p: Among these association models, one that most parsimoniously fits the data, as indicated by the smallest BIC value, is the simple heterogeneous row-effects association model hypothesizing that (1) races differ only in the extent of overall association, and (2) happiness has an interval scale of equal spacing. The more parsimonious fit of the row-effect association model compared with the RC association model indicates that being “pretty happy” is almost exactly in between “very happy” and “not happy” in the association of happiness with marital status.

Table 6 presents the parameter estimates of the simple heterogeneous row-effects association model. The coefficient of intrinsic association, together with the fact that this model improves the fit of the homogeneous row-effects association model, indicates that the effect of marital status on happiness is smaller for African Americans than for other races. Second, the row-effects scores indicate that being “married” is by far the happiest marital status, followed by “never married,”“divorced,”“widowed,” and “separated” in that order.

caption.p: Parameter Estimates of the Simple Heterogeneous Row-effects Association Modela

fn.label: a
fn.p:
Column-effects scores are fixed at
1 /
2
for “very happy,” 0 for “pretty happy,” and
− 1 /
2
for “not happy.”

sec.title: 8. Conclusions
sec.p: Although log-linear and log-multiplicative association models are useful for the analysis of cross-classified frequency data, their major limitations have been (1) their inability to use many control variables and (2) their lack of association with causal analysis. A multivariate regression analysis of a categorical dependent variable, such as multinomial logit regression model, provided only a partial remedy for those limitations, because it usually makes a strong assumption that there are linear additive effects of control variables, and because the type of association that can be tested is limited. This article introduces a new method that greatly reduces these limitations.

The log-linear causal analysis introduced in this article enables the analysis of association between two focal variables and the possible dependence of that association on a third variable, by controlling for confounding effects of many covariates without the parametric modeling of covariate effects as used in multivariate regression models. I hope that the method introduced here leads to a resurgence of interest in log-linear and log-multiplicative analyses in sociological research that includes many categorical variables for assessing causes and consequences.

The major limitation of the method introduced in this article for causal analysis, however, is the assumed absence of unobserved confounding variables, as the same limitation applies to any use of propensity-score methods with the SITA assumption in causal analysis.

sec.title: On the Specification of Association Models Using LEM
sec.p: Table C1 presents the LEM program used for the application of the simple heterogeneous row-effect association model of Table 4. The “man” statement specifies the number of manifest (or observed) variables. The label (“lab”) statement specifies variable labels, and labels G, R, and C are used respectively for the group variable (race), the row variable (marital status), and the column variable (happiness) of Table 3, and the “dim” statement indicates the number of their categories. The model (“mod”) statement specifies a model and indicates that the model uses parameters to fix the GR and GC marginal distributions and parameters for the specified form of conditional association and it uses cell weights for the three-way table. The entry “ass2(R,C,G,3b)” in the model statement specifies the simple heterogeneous row-effect association model. The statement “sta wei(GRC)” indicates that cell weights are given by numbers in the following bracket by a three-way array GRC. The cell weight for each cell is the ratio of the observed sample count to the adjusted frequency on the basis of the data of Table 3. The specifications for the other association models of Table 5 only differ in the third entry of the model statement, and they are as follows (Vermunt 1997a):

list-item.p: Heterogeneous row, homogeneous column effect association: ass2(R,C,G,5c)
Homogeneous row, heterogeneous column effect association: ass2(R,C,G,5d)
Heterogeneous row, heterogeneous column effect association: ass2(R,C,G,5e)

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The author declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The author disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article: This research was supported at its outset by research grant SES-0617202 from the National Science Foundation to the author.

Gail et al. (1984) concluded that “certain important nonlinear regression models lead to biased estimates of treatment effect, even in randomized setting, if needed covariates are omitted” (p. 341) and that “the asymptotic bias from omitting covariates is shown to be zero if the regression of the response variable on treatment and covariates is linear or exponential, and in regular cases, this is a necessary condition for zero bias” (p. 341). What the authors referred to here as the “exponential” case includes the log-linear probability model of equation 5b given later.

Little and Pullum (1979) proved a part of this theorem for the case in which the link function is equal to the standardization function. According to the author, no proof was presented in a general form with the standardization function for the case with
s ( x ) = exp ( l ( x ) )
before an unpublished paper by Yamaguchi (2009).

A 6-category distinction for the type of place lived at age 16, a trichotomous distinction of race, and a 10-category distinction of the region of residence at age 16 were also examined in the preliminary analysis, but they were either omitted or reduced in the number of categories to be distinguished because of either nonsignificance or very weak significance.

bio.title: Bio
bio.p: Kazuo Yamaguchi is the Hanna Holborn Gray Professor of Sociology at the University of Chicago. His book on work-life balance and low fertility was published recently in both Japanese and Korean.
